#Text=Maitatsine
#Text=This article is about the preacher .
#Text=For the military officer , see Mohammed Buba Marwa .
#Text=Mohammed Marwa ( died 1980 ) , best known by his nickname Maitatsine , was a controversial preacher in Nigeria .
#Text=Maitatsine is a Hausa word meaning " the one who damns " and refers to his curse-laden public speeches against the Nigerian state . [ 1 ]

column1: #Text=His militant followers are known as the Yan Tatsine .
#Text=Background
#Text=He was originally from Marwa in northern Cameroon . [ 2 ]
#Text=After his education he moved to Kano , Nigeria in about 1945 , where he became known for his controversial preachings on the Qur'an .
#Text=Maitatsine spoke against the use of radios , watches , bicycles , cars and the possession of more money than necessary . [ 3 ] [ 4 ]
#Text=The British colonial authorities sent him into exile , but he returned to Kano shortly after independence .
#Text=By 1972 he had a notable and increasingly militant following known as Yan Tatsine . [ 4 ]

#Text=In 1975 he was again arrested by Nigerian police for slander and public abuse of political authorities [ 2 ] But in that period he began to receive acceptance from religious authorities , especially after making hajj , the Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca . [ 2 ]
#Text=As his following increased in the 1970s , so did the number of confrontations between his adherents and the police .
#Text=His preaching attracted largely a following of youths , unemployed migrants , and those who felt that mainstream Muslim teachers were not doing enough for their communities .
#Text=By December 1980 , continued Yan Tatsine attacks on other religious figures and police forced the Nigerian army to become involved .
#Text=Subsequent armed clashes led to the deaths of around 5,000 people , including Maitatsine himself . [ 4 ]
#Text=Maitatsine died shortly after sustaining injuries in the clashes either from his wounds or from a heart attack . [ 5 ]
#Text=According to a 2010 article published by the Sunday Trust magazine
#Text=the military cremated Maitatsine 's remains , which now rest in a bottle kept at a police laboratory in Kano . [ 6 ]
#Text=Legacy
#Text=Despite Mohammed Marwa 's death , Yan Tatsine riots continued into the early 1980s .
#Text=In October 1982 riots erupted in Bulumkuttu , near Maidaguri , [ 7 ] and in Kaduna , [ 7 ] to where many Yan Tatsine adherents had moved after 1980 .
#Text=Over 3,000 people died .
#Text=Some survivors of these altercations moved to Yola , and in early 1984 more violent uprisings occurred in that city . [ 7 ]
#Text=In this round of rioting , Musa Makaniki , a close disciple of Maitatsine , emerged as a leader and Marwa 's successor . [ 4 ] [ 5 ]
#Text=Ultimately more than 1,000 people died in Yola and roughly half of the city 's 60,000 inhabitants were left homeless .
#Text=Makaniki fled to his hometown of Gombe , [ 7 ] where more Yan Tatsine riots occurred in April 1985 .
#Text=After the deaths of several hundred people Makaniki retreated to Cameroon , where he remained until 2004 when he was arrested in Nigeria . [ 4 ]
#Text=Some analysts view the terrorist group Boko Haram as an extension of the Maitatsine riots . [ 8 ]
#Text=Literature
#Text=Allan Christelow , Abdalla Uba Adamu : Art . " Mai Tatsine " in John L. Esposito ( ed . ) : The Oxford Encyclopedia of the Islamic World .
#Text=6 Bde. Oxford 2009 .
#Text=Bd . III , S. 459-462.
